unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecommunications provider, Bharti Airtel, announced today an accelerated rollout of its fiber-to-home (FTTH) network across several Tier II and Tier III cities in India. The expansion aims to connect an additional 5 million homes over the next two years, bringing high-speed internet access to underserved regions.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecommunications provider, Bharti Airtel, announced today an accelerated rollout of its fiber-to-home (F T T H) network across several Tier two and Tier three cities in India. The expansion aims to connect an additional five million homes over the next two years, bringing high-speed internet access to underserved regions.

unnormalised: Dr. Rajesh Kumar, Chief Technology Officer at Airtel, stated the company is investing Rs. 5000 crore in infrastructure upgrades, including laying over 20,000 km of optical fiber cable. The initiative will prioritize areas with a high density of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and educational institutions, fostering digital literacy and economic growth.
normalised: Doctor Rajesh Kumar, Chief Technology Officer at Airtel, stated the company is investing rupee five thousand crore in infrastructure upgrades, including laying over twenty thousand kilometer of optical fiber cable. The initiative will prioritize areas with a high density of small and medium-sized enterprises (S M E s) and educational institutions, fostering digital literacy and economic growth.

unnormalised: The rollout will begin in cities such as Jaipur, Lucknow, and Coimbatore, with plans to expand to other regions progressively. Airtel is also partnering with local construction firms to expedite the process and minimize disruption. Furthermore, the company plans to bundle its FTTH service with its existing mobile and DTH offerings, providing customers with a comprehensive suite of telecommunication services. New plans for residential buildings with floor sizes starting from 500 sq ft are also in the offing.
